data.name: Check if graph is bipartite
data.description:
A [Bipartite Graph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartite_graph) is a graph whose vertices can be divided into two disjoint sets *U* and *V* such that every edge connects a vertex in *U* to one in *V*.

![Example Bipartite Graph](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Simple_bipartite_graph%3B_two_layers.svg/2880px-Simple_bipartite_graph%3B_two_layers.svg.png)
This graph is bipartite because the numbered vertices and the lettered vertices can each be put into their own set such that there are no edges internal to either set.

![Example not Bipartite Graph](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Complete_graph_K3.svg/1920px-Complete_graph_K3.svg.png)
This graph is not bipartite, because no matter which way you split up the 3 vertices into two groups, there will always be at least one edge within a group.

You are given an undirected graph passed as a list of edges like so:
```python
[
  (1, 2),
  (2, 3),
  (3, 1)
]
```
Each edge is a 2-tuple of integers with each element being the ID of a node at one end of the edge. Given this graph, write a method that returns `True` if the graph is bipartite and `False` if it is not.

Notes:
* The partitioning of a bipartite graph into two distinct sets is not necessarily unique.
* You may assume that the vertices of the graph are exactly the numbers that appear in at least one edge.
* The same edge may or may not appear more than once.
* The edges `(1, 2)` and `(2, 1)` are the same edge. The list of edges might have one or both.
* It is possible for an edge to connect a node to itself.
* The graph is not necessarily a single connected component.
